anchor: What role does leadership play in organizational effectiveness?
positive: Though not the focus of this chapter, leadership is essential and often the cause of problems and failures if not executed correctly.

anchor: What do large projects resemble in terms of organization and team member identity?
positive: In particular, large projects represent small, autonomously organized units whose team members have a clearly defined goal and tasks and a recognized identity distinguishing them from “the rest” for a period of time.

anchor: What legitimizes a project manager’s claim to leadership in project execution?
positive: A project manager’s claim to leadership for exe- cuting a project under his or her sole responsibility is legitimized by an announcement and assignment of obligations and authority by the management of the organization and is based on the mission and project goals.

anchor: What personal characteristic of a project manager involves aligning with the project's mission and objectives?
positive: Clearly, the following personal characteristics and behavior of a project manager contribute to a project’s success:e Identification with the mission objectives and project goals.e Capability of teamworke Capability of motivatinge Capability of moderatinge Fairness and transparencye Communication behaviore Abstraction and analytical capabilitiese Verbal and rhetorical skills

anchor: What is the ability to evaluate one's own actions and improve from experiences called?
positive: e Capability of self-criticism and learning

anchor: How do project characteristics influence partner trust and management perceptions?
positive: Which of these capabilities will positively affect the project depend on the kind of project, its criticality, size and complexity, as well as on the team members and institutions involved.2/25/09 3:36:34 PM 9.1 Management of Space ProjectsLoss of trust by the project partners caused by insufficient capabilities is often attributed to “bad management” and is difficult to regain.

anchor: What is the significance of maintaining oversight and adjustments in project management?
positive: 9.1.3.3 Project Control

anchor: What aspects are essential for evaluating the performance of a project through monitoring?
positive: An essential task of project management is monitoring project performance.The objective is to determine the actual project parameters and factors in correlation with plan- ned values, as well as to analyze deviations and consequences by defining preventive and corrective measures.The most important elements of this assessment are:e Technical approache Time and implementation schedule.

anchor: Who receives the internal status report summarizing assessment results?
positive: The results of assessments are summarized in an internal status report delivered to the internal ma- nagement or, if requested and contractually agreed, to the customer.

anchor: What is crucial for effective project management among team members?
positive: 9.1.3.4 Communication and ReportingCommunication between project team members is an essential instrument of effective and successful project management (see Figure 9.1.1). The content and amount of the needed communication effort is related to the tasks and interests of the project partners involved (see Table 9.1.1).

anchor: What are the consequences of poor communication in project management?
positive: By no means should this management task be underestimated, because bad communication gene- rates mistrust and dissatisfaction and always results in bad project relationships.

anchor: What are essential elements for effective communication within a project team?
positive: The portfolio of successful project management includes the following tasks.Interfaces to the Project Team:e Regular team meetingse Up-to-date and complete exchange of informatione Positive and negative feedbacke Formulation of problemse Clear task requirementse Clear and unambiguous work package descrip- tions757 e Efficient workloads which avoid continuous over- burdening.

The following information should be provided as a minimum:

positive: e Project progress, including the most important events of the reporting period

positive: e Planned activities for the next reporting periode Agreed deviations or discrepancies from functio- nal requirements and specificationse Identified problem areas and riskse Actual schedule, including work accomplished to datee Status of cash flow and planninge Technical budgets, control and schedules.

anchor: What is suggested for maintaining contact with customer representatives?
positive: Furthermore, verbal communications with the customer’s representatives on a regular basis are re- commended, as is the provision of ad-hoc information in case of critical events.

anchor: What is the purpose of maintaining a detailed schedule in large programs?
positive: Additionally, it is recommended that all data and information is stored on a jointly accessible project ser- ver to allow the customer to carry out ad-hoc reviews and evaluation of documentation. As an example, con- sider the master schedule. This schedule is discussed only at the highest level due to its extraordinary size in the case of large programs. However, a detailed and complete schedule covering all working levels must be updated at appropriate intervals and always available to facilitate transparent communication..

Figure 9.1.18 shows a typical example of a line organization.

anchor: What challenges arise in managing project teams with diverse disciplines?
positive: Due to the interdisciplinary character of projects it may be difficult to establish and guide project teams. Cooperation and control may be difficult, particularly in cases of conflict since the decision path and process are complex and time consuming.

anchor: What type of organizational structure is recommended for programs that require flexibility and systematic approaches?
positive: Such structures may lead to inefficient burea- ucracy and are not useful for large-scale projects. For programs requiring flexible and systematic structures, a matrix organization is recommended (Figure 9.1.19).In this organizational form the management establishes a project team under the control of the leading project manager. An example of this for a satellite project is shown in Figure 9.1.20.9.1.4.2 Model Philosophy

anchor: What phases finalize the model philosophy in programs adhering to the ESA approach?
positive: The model philosophy is developed from the mission and program requirements. For programs following the ESA approach the model philosophy is developed in Phase A and finalized in Phase B.

anchor: What factors influence the selection of models related to verification and testing processes?
positive: The variances are based on value for money, quality and risk considerations, and define the kind of models to be developed, including the depth of verification and test spectrum. See also Figure 9.1.16 and Section 8.3.2.

anchor: What role does the project manager play in the solution selection process according to the model philosophy?
positive: Although the model philosophy is developed by technical engineers, the project manager supports the decision process for selecting an optimized solution. Only when the types and number of models and processes are agreed can they be considered in the implementation planning.

anchor: What is a common reason procurement programs produce only flight models?
positive: Procurement programs with minimum deve- lopment risks produce only flight models for cost reasons and because they can rely on the long ex- perience of manufacturers. Qualification models or prototypes are usually not considered. However, it is not unusual that even in flight models components or items are used which are not available as commercial off-the-shelf(COTS) products and which have to be specially developed for the program..

anchor: What is the primary objective of managing uncertainties within a project or organization?
positive: 9.1.4.3 Risk Management

anchor: What are the preventive strategies in risk management to minimize project damage?
positive: Risk management must identify and eliminate risks as early as possible with appropriate preventive measures to avoid or limit possible damage which may materi- alize during the program. Thus the focus must be on risks which may affect the success of the mission or project. Additionally, risk management supports the achievement of realistic schedule, cost, and resource planning for the program.

anchor: What elements are crucial for documenting risks in a matrix related to project management?
positive: Risk must be identified and included in a risk matrix with keyword information on the following items:e RiskItem Description: Description of the risk with respect to cost, time and quality requirements.e Cause of Risk: Summary of all possible causes for the risk.e Description of Consequence: Summary of conse- quences and impact on project success and costs.

anchor: How is the likelihood of risk occurrence quantified in terms of percentage?
positive: e Probability of Risk (1-100%): Estimation of probability of risk occurrence.

anchor: How is the criticality of a risk determined using probability and effect?
positive: e Effect of Risk (1-10): Evaluation of the risk effect based on predefined criteria.° Criticality of Risk: Calculated by multiplying the risk probability by the effect of the risk.e Recovery Indicator (time in months): Estimate of time within which the risk effect can be corrected, for calculating repair costs.e Risk Owner: Designation by the PM of the person responsible for managing the risk.

anchor: What are preventive measures employed to minimize risk in technical processes?
positive: e Technical Mitigation: Description of preventive technical measures for avoiding risk.

anchor: What is the role of project management in monitoring defined measures related to risks?
positive: e Contractual Mitigation: Description of contrac- tual measures to control risks.© Contingency: Description of measures which have to be initiated if the risk occurs.All the defined resulting measures must be monitored on a regular basis by project management and their status reported to and discussed with the internal management.9.1.4.4 Cost and Schedule Planning

anchor: What elements must be included in a comprehensive schedule for program monitoring?
positive: The main contractor must work out an overall sche- dule for program monitoring and control in which all relevant measures, work and process steps and milestones are included. In this sense the schedule may be seen as the transfer of work package descriptions into processes; these also include all the tasks assigned to subcontractors.

positive: 2/25/09 3:36:36 PM CHO9.indd Sec1:760Income inspection |] Integration Verification Acceptance Delivery CommissioningFigure 9.1.21: System- atics of the schedule.For effective project control each process mustprovide the following information:e Task description of the individual process stee Work package numbere Responsible partner (name and organization)

anchor: What are the key types of milestones recognized in project management that include review, MIP, and KIP?
positive: e Identification of milestones (review, MIP, KIP)

anchor: What are the components of cost that can be categorized in project management?
positive: e Cost elements (fixed costs, variable costs, travel costs)e Time duration with date of project start and fixed limitationse Documents to be provided on completion of the work package (if applicable).The following aspects are therefore essential:e Allsubsequent process steps must follow a closed loop concept and a standard structure with the following contents:

anchor: What processes are involved in acquiring and managing specific assignments like inspections and KIP?
positive: — Receiving tasks (e.g., KIP, inspection)

anchor: What is required for efficient execution of planning tasks in project management?
positive: — Approval, checking task results— Delivery/handover to the next subprocess.e Linking of all relevant processes according to the workflow.Only if the above requirements are fulfilled can the planning tasks be efficiently performed. These are: e Establishment and maintenance of a master plan9 Management of Space ProjectsSubsystem Level Component levelPurchase order Planning Design

anchor: What are the key elements involved in the acquisition of essential parts for a project?
positive: | Procurement — components

anchor: What process involves evaluating key activities and their duration in a project?
positive: Procurement — components|roduction QualificationFactory acceptance Deliverye Analysis of the critical pathe Presentation of project reports (cost summary, resource capacity and consumption, status)e Presentation of Gantt diagrams Presentation of Pert diagrams Change management.The use of commonly available software tools for project planning and control is recommended.

anchor: What is the significance of making the project schedule accessible to all collaborators?
positive: Because of the importance of project planning, the schedule for the project should be available to all project partners on a common server.

anchor: What is the significance of subdividing large-scale space programs into smaller projects?
positive: Due to the increasing complexity of large-scale space programs, thousands of individual process steps may be necessary to achieve the mission goal. In this case it is essential to subdivide the overall project into smaller projects and to link them accordingly (see Figure 9.1.21).

anchor: What key aspects should be considered for effective schedule management and functionality assurance?
positive: To better manage the schedule and assure its func- tionality, the following aspects should be the basis for its implementation:

anchor: What is the significance of maintaining uniform detail levels across different subprocesses of a project?
positive: e Clarity of single (sub)processese Similar level of detail for each processe Product/process-oriented structure of the sche- dulee Integration of internal milestones as KIPe Integration of subcontractor and supplier mi- lestonese Color coding of essential process steps2/25/09 3:36:37 PM 9.1 Management of Space Projects

anchor: What is the potential impact of minimizing connections between larger segments in a workflow?
positive: e Linking of individual work steps within larger blocks; minimization of links across blocks.

anchor: How should the frequency of synchronization and updates change throughout a project's timeline?
positive: Maintenance of the schedule should be carried out and coordinated by project management to assure in-time control and monitoring of the progress of work.The synchronization and updating intervals should be shortened as the project progresses, from two months at the beginning of the project down to a weekly update sequence for critical activities. The level of detail should increase accordingly.

anchor: What are the core elements involved in ensuring quality management in processes or products?
positive: 9.1.4.5 Quality Management Aspects

anchor: What are the two roles of quality management in achieving project and product quality?
positive: Quality management plays both a preventive and a corrective role in achieving high project and product quality; the goal is reliable and efficient project per- formance to reach the mission aims.

anchor: What role do in-house standards play in optimizing processes for project goals?
positive: International standards for space applications (ECSS), industrial applications (ISO) and in-house rules are applicable. The application of in-house stan- dards is meant to ensure that the optimized, qualified and certified processes of the companies involved in the project are used to achieve the program goals.

anchor: What must quality assurance standards consider when being tailored for projects?
positive: Quality assurance standards may be tailored to technical and programmatic requirements, cost and time demands and should take the experience of former projects (heritage) into account.It is the task of the management to establish an effi- cient quality assurance or product assurance process which is independent of the engineering process and reports directly to the project management.

anchor: What is the primary purpose of managing configurations in a project?
positive: 9.1.4.6 Configuration Management

anchor: What is the main purpose of documenting services, functions, and requirements in configuration management?
positive: The goal of configuration management is to docu- ment the status of delivered services, functions and physical requirements, providing full transparency. Software, hardware, drawings and documents are to be documented and archived, in each case with the revision status, so that an overview of the “as-built” status is available at any time.

anchor: What does configuration management identify in the configuration item data list?
positive: Configuration management documents the pro- duct tree and identifies all hardware and software in the configuration item data list (CIDL).

anchor: What role does configuration management play in relation to quality management systems?
positive: Configuration management may be seen as a sup- porting process, controlled by the quality managementsystems of the organization (e.g., according to ISO 9001 and ISO EN 9100).9.1.4.7 Logistic Aspects

anchor: What is essential to implement early in operational phases to reduce life cycle costs?
positive: In order to support economical services or opera- tions with minimum life cycle costs, the basics of integrated logistic support (ILS) and logistic sup- port analysis (LSA) should be applied early in the operational phases, in particular to support efficient interoperability with other missions (multimission compatibility).

anchor: What are the primary components that constitute the significant cost items in a specific project assessment?
positive: The number of items to be controlled is based on the product tree and must be included in the cost plan. The most important cost items include:e Space segment (development and procurement): — Satellite platform — Payload compound — Test and analyses — Orbit transfer

anchor: What aspects are included in the operation of ground segments?
positive: e Ground segment: — Infrastructure (leasing rates) — Technical equipment (leasing rates and purchasing) — Operation (including leasing rates) — Ground support equipment

anchor: What factors must be analyzed regarding mean time for repair in project management?
positive: e Program management, for example: — Project and quality management — Procurement and purchasinge Disposal of all products e Personnel cost and training/qualification e Maintenance and spare partse Changes and modifications to hardware and software.In particular, requirements concerning mean time for repair (MTFR) must be analyzed and evaluated appropriately.

anchor: What does a standardized ILS concept for mission operation aim to provide information about regarding components and services?
positive: Business models for selected components and services of the space segment as well as the ground segment (including personnel, training and qualifica- tion) require a standardized ILS concept for mission operation. This should provide information on:

anchor: What are the key considerations in managing materials and tools during construction projects?
positive: e Logistic requirements for construction, reliability, material stability2/25/09 3:36:37 PM CHO9.indd Sec1:762e Maintenance and management of materials and tools (overall concept, stages as required, equip- ment pools)e Software maintenance and changee Storage, conservation, packing and labeling, in particularly for long lead itemse Cataloging and indexinge Training and training tools.

anchor: What are some critical considerations when assessing the effectiveness of information technology security measures?
positive: 9.1.4.8 IT Security Aspects

anchor: What are the four main attributes that IT security aims to guarantee for information?
positive: The function of IT security is to handle, store and communicate information in such a way that its security (confidentiality), integrity, availability and authenticity are assured.Security of data means that information about and data resulting from operations and services are only provided to authorized persons or organizations.

anchor: What does integrity refer to in the context of data security?
positive: Integrity means the protection of data against manipulation and disturbance.

anchor: List the four categories of measures taken to ensure data security during satellite transport and storage.
positive: To assure data security, various measures must be taken which can be categorized into four groups and are described in the following.e Safe locking of the satellite transport container for transport to the launch pade Encryption of data transfer and transmissione Safe storage on secured data storage media

anchor: What are the primary functions of firewalls in securing networks against cyber threats?
positive: e Installation and operation of firewalls for pro- tection against hacking, data manipulation and deletion

anchor: What measures should be established to ensure secure areas and access control during different operational phases?
positive: e Use of crypto unitse Authentication by passwords.Organizational Measures:e Definition of responsibilities and authorization of ground segment operations personnele Complete documentation control of corrective, installation and maintenance work on hardware and software.Infrastructural Measures: e Establishment of secure areas including access control adapted to specific operational phases.

anchor: What are the primary objectives of implementing employee security assessments in an organization?
positive: Personnel Measures: e Security checks of personnel

anchor: What is essential to prevent the unauthorized transfer of confidential project data?
positive: 9 Management of Space Projectse Agreements with the personnel involved to ensure that data classified as confidential is not transferred to unauthorized persons.

anchor: What factors influence the effort involved in implementing security measures in a project?
positive: The effort in carrying out the measures briefly de- scribed above depends on the requirements and size of the project. On request they may be analyzed and defined in a security concept which is integrated into the program by project management.

anchor: What primary concern does safety management focus on in project realization?
positive: 9.1.4.9 Safety AspectsNational and international laws and regulations require specific consideration of safety-relevant as- pects during realization of a project.Safety is primarily related to human safety, that is to prevent injury or death, but it is also related to damage to satellites and lower level subsystems and components.

anchor: What phases should safety evaluations be incorporated into when dealing with satellite projects?
positive: Safety aspects must be analyzed systematically and considered throughout the entire AIT process as well as during the life cycle of a satellite.

anchor: What are the minimum activities included in the mission safety program?
positive: The mission safety program consists of the fol- lowing activities as a minimum:e Definition of safety-relevant requirements in the context of a product assurance and safety (PA&S) plane Performance of a tailored safety analysis.

anchor: What elements are considered in the analysis of the entire product tree in spacecraft projects?
positive: These measures take into account the complete pro- duct tree, in particular work on the spacecraft and use of ground support equipment (GSE) as well as transport and lifting tools.

anchor: What are the goals of conducting a safety analysis at the start of a program?
positive: Work at the launch pad is controlled by the rele- vant site safety procedures.The safety analysis is performed at the beginning of the program with the aim of identifying safety- critical items and considering appropriate measures early in the design so that the relevant processes are covered.Typical safety-relevant aspects are:e Injury and illnesse Temperature and pressure extremes

anchor: What management strategies are crucial for the successful execution of space projects?
positive: 2/25/09 3:36:37 PM 9.1 Management of Space Projects

anchor: What is developed based on safety analysis and critical areas in a project context?
positive: e Falls e  Lacerations.On the basis of the safety analysis and the identified critical areas, specific safety procedures are developed and monitored by the safety engineer.9.1.5 Project Management Documentation9.1.5.1 Management Plan

anchor: What phase of a space program is designated for the establishment of the management plan according to ESA requirements?
positive: The management plan is an element of the design and planning work (see Figure 9.1.22), and has to be established in Phase A of a space program according to ESA requirements.

anchor: What phase involves establishing a management plan related to technical realization and project constraints?
positive: The phase of determining concepts and specifi- cations leads to the establishment of a management plan which defines and describes the structural and methodical approaches and the resulting processes required to successfully meet the mission goals with respect to technical realization, time plan and cost framework.

anchor: What must happen to the management plan at the kick-off of the implementation phase?
positive: The management plan is structured in such a way that, as the program proceeds, modifications can be easily made or incorporated into the project handbook (see Section 9.1.5.2), up until kick-off of the imple- mentation phase (Phases C and D). At this milestone the management plan must be finalized and subject to document control.

anchor: What defines the essential goals and tasks of a project or operation?

anchor: What must be certified and implemented before handling space products?

anchor: What process does quality assurance utilize to ensure product generation meets management standards?

This is not to be understood as bureau- cratization, but as a measure which guarantees the objectivity of the quality assurance processes.

anchor: What does the abbreviation PA stand for in the context of quality assurance for space products?
positive: Product Assurance Quality assurance for space products is referred to as product assurance (PA).

anchor: What does product assurance convert into space-specific methodologies for generating products?
positive: Product assurance translates generic quality assu- rance into space-specific processes needed for pro- duct generation. These processes are oriented to the rules and regulations of customer organizations such as ESA, NASA, DLR, as well as those of launcher aut- horities and user organizations such as Arianespace, COSMOS, METEOSAT, SES and ASTRA. Product assurance supports project management in carrying out the product life cycle and supervising product generation according to the customer’s programmatic and technical requirements, and based on experience and lessons learned..

anchor: Which standards influence the general requirements for quality management according to the provided context?

These are complemented by customer-specific requirements, requirements for technology processes, as well as by direct or indirect rules and regulations under the laws of those countries and communities in which the product is to be used. The customer-specific re- quirements of major space agencies are summarized in Section 9.2.6.4..

anchor: How does quality management contribute to procurement in project management?
positive: Quality management supports project management in the procurement process, in compliance with the required quality standards and approved manufactu- rers and suppliers.

anchor: What certifications are prioritized when selecting a supplier for product quality in aerospace?
positive: Manufacturer and supplier are selected in compliance with the product quality requirements. The selection can be either from an existing supplier list provi- ded by the major space agencies, or on the basis of specific technology requirements. For the selection and assignment of suppliers, special concern is given to their ISO certification and their ability to meet customer requirements. In case of any doubts as to their adequacy, or in the case of a new supplier, a sup- plier audit is conducted by quality management.

anchor: What is the requirement for supplier audits in relation to contract awards?
positive: The audit results are reported to the customer on request. Supplier audits must always be completed before the awarding of a contract..

anchor: What three types of audits are conducted for suppliers after the initial audit?
positive: Part of the audit is checking the supplier’s compli- ance with the generic quality requirements of the ISO standards, the product requirements and the supplier's qualification to carry out specified technological processes. Subsequent supplier audits are divided into quality audits, project audits and process audits.2/25/09 3:36:45 PM CHO9.indd Sect:774

anchor: Who directs each audit according to the provided guidelines?
positive: Each audit is directed by quality management, supported by engineering disciplines, if deemed ne- cessary.

anchor: What must occur for each new contract in relation to audits?
positive: Audits are always product associated and must be repeated for each new contract.The audit performance and results are docu- mented by quality management and included in the organization’s list of approved suppliers.

anchor: What criteria are used to evaluate approved suppliers?
positive: The rating of approved suppliers is based on qualitative and quantitative criteria concerning tech- nical and commercial competence and reliability. The rating must support the selection and may be as follows:

anchor: What action is required if a supplier is rated as 'sufficient' for over two years?
positive: If a supplier is rated as “sufficient” for more than two years, a control audit must be performed; if a supplier is rated as “not sufficient” after two years, it must be removed from the supplier list.

anchor: What requirements must be met to utilize suppliers not on the approved list for space products?
positive: ESA maintains a list of suppliers approved for space products. They are audited by ESA and can be used by the organization without the need for an additional audit. Any deviation from space-approved suppliers must be reasonable and must in any case be negotiated with the customer.

anchor: What type of document must the supplier provide to confirm project-specific quality compliance upon product delivery?
positive: The organization’s general quality requirements must be contractually accepted by the supplier in a written quality agreement signed by both parties. The project- specific quality requirements must be contractually accepted by the supplier, who provides a certificate of conformance upon delivery of the product.

anchor: Who is primarily responsible for overseeing the planning of a production process?
positive: Supervised production requires production plan- ning and control. Production planning describes the production flow and all tasks required for pro- duction, such as preparatory work, work scheduling, integration and test planning. Production planning is performed by the production manager supported by system engineering and product assurance staff.

anchor: What prerequisites are essential for ensuring the quality of space project production processes?

anchor: What documents outline tools, materials, and personnel for specific processes in production?

Each process execution is documented in a report to be checked by those responsible for product assurance.

anchor: What factors influence the selection of manufacturers and testing facilities in production management?
positive: The production manager checks the manufac- turing on site according to customer, technology or quality-specific criteria. The selection of manufactu- rers and test facilities is a combined activity involving engineering disciplines, product assurance and project management.

anchor: What is essential to follow for space products during production and testing to prevent issues?
positive: All steps and processes needed for production, integration and testing are identified and scheduled in a manufacturing, integration and test plan. Key characteristics, inspections and acceptances are iden- tified and scheduled in a dedicated inspection plan. For space products, environmental restrictions and contamination controls must be respected.

Transportation and handling must be described in specific manuals with identification of warnings of safety hazards, special precautions and dangerous goods by references to pu- blic authorities.

anchor: What approach is used for the implementation of corrective measures in the design assurance process?
positive: Design assurance starts with the conceptual product phase and continues in the predevelopment and deve- lopment phases up until the final design. The implementati- on of corrective measures follows the reverse approach, “bottom-up,” to assure consolidation of requirements from the lowest level to the system level..

anchor: What types of analyses must be performed for reliability assurance during product phases?

anchor: What is the focus of product assurance in relation to maintenance activities?

anchor: What are the key tasks involved in ensuring that products can be maintained effectively?

anchor: What are the primary components involved in executing a safety assurance program for space products?
positive: The main activities of safety assurance comprise the definition of safety requirements for a space product, the preparation of safety analyses, the implementation of safety measures and design controls in the deve- lopment phase, the verification of safety operations, and the performance of customer-required safety reviews. The accomplishment of a safety program is based mainly on the requirements specified by the space agencies and the launch authorities.

anchor: What types of hazard potentials are addressed in the reviewed safety document?

anchor: What is the purpose of functional and operational safety analyses in safety-critical systems?

Selection, quality standard checks and acceptance of metallic and nonmetallic materials and the asso- ciated production and inspection procedures must be verified for each construction element before use in a space product.

anchor: What elements are crucial for effective product assurance in organizational operations?
positive: Effective product assurance relies on work contri- butions from other operational functions in the organization and from the project. The technical and administrative interfaces are described in the work breakdown structure (WBS), their associated work package descriptions (WPDs) and the common project milestone reviews and documentation.

anchor: What type of specification is created by contractors for accommodating customer requirements?
positive: Usually the product requirements are specified in the customer requirement specification included in the statement of work (SOW). These are accommodated by the contractor in the form of a design specification for the system, the subsystems, the operations and the associated work package descriptions (WPD). It is essential that all requirements be completely iden- tified, collected and documented before the contract. They are contractually committing and must be expli- citly verified until the project comes to an end..

anchor: What is crucial to resolve with the client prior to initiating a project to ensure clarity in specifications?
positive: The specifications contain the design require- ments, operational requirements, environmental requirements, quality standards for parts, materials and components, as well as the deliverable product models. The requirements must be broken down to all product levels, as system, subsystem, equipment and component levels. Special concerns have to be addressed concerning the functional and physical interfaces between these levels, the payload and the interface in human space projects. Incomplete, unclear or contradicting requirements must be negotiated with the customer before the project starts..

anchor: What considerations are important when choosing quality benchmarks for a project?
positive: 9.2.6.6 Selection of Quality Standards

anchor: What factors influence the choice of quality standards in product development?
positive: The selection of appropriate quality standards is pri- marily oriented along the functional requirements, the environmental loads and the predicted operational lifetime. The standards may differ, depending on the maintenance concepts, especially for human space products. The quality standards differ for the required product models, of which the flight model has the highest quality standards.

anchor: What implications arise from employing a redundancy strategy regarding component quality standards?
positive: Additional selection criteria derive from the reli- ability and availability requirements and the chosen redundancy concept. In the case of sufficient redun- dancies the quality standards for components may be

anchor: What must be documented in compliance lists by product assurance?
positive: reduced, but on the other hand they may have to be increased in the case of insufficient redundancies. All selected quality standards must be checked by product assurance and documented in compliance lists.

anchor: What fundamental ideas underpin the philosophy guiding product model development?
positive: 9.2.6.7 Product Model Philosophy

anchor: What aspects of project planning is influenced by the defined model philosophy?
positive: The definition of the model philosophy is especially important for product development and production. It has a direct impact on qualification planning, pro- curement planning and hardware cost. The selected quality standards must be related to the different product models. Model hardware cost and hardware procurement sources as well as the procurement time have to be identified early in the project proposal phase. In order to meet the project schedule it is in any case recommended that alternative hardware procurement sources be identified..

anchor: What are the primary differences in purpose between the Engineering Model and the Flight Model in aerospace projects?
positive: Engineering (Qualification) Model and Flight Model

anchor: What is the primary purpose of the engineering model in relation to flight qualification testing?
positive: For this “two-model” philosophy the engineering model (EM) serves as a development model which is identical to the flight model (FM) in form, fit and function. In exceptional and reasonable cases it is permissible to use lower quality standards for EEE components. Therefore the failure risk is relatively high but controllable. The EM is used for flight qua- lification testing (EQM) including environmental testing. Design improvements, modifications and repairs are allowed..

anchor: What type of hardware is used in the reproduction of the qualified engineering model?
positive: The subsequent FM is a reproduction of the qua- lified EM but with flight-standard hardware. The FM undergoes acceptance testing with lower testing levels than for the EQM. As depicted in the schematic of Figure 9.2.9, the risk of failures in the FM is signi- ficantly reduced by this “two-model” philosophy. Residual but controllable risks can occur during system integration when the interfaces between the different subsystems and payloads are verified. These risks cannot be significantly reduced and remain even if additional models are used..

anchor: What are the primary risks associated with the integration of elements for functional interaction?
positive: model. The failure risk on the element and component levels is lower than in the EM, presuming that the environmental qualifications have been performed on the component, equipment and subsystem levels before PFM integration. The main risk now occurs during integration of these elements for functional interaction. Experience from an upstream EQM does not exist, which increases the failure risk until func- tional testing on the integrated system level.

anchor: How can risks be managed during environmental tests when using a combined qualification and acceptance approach?
positive: The risk during environmental tests with a combined qualifi- cation/acceptance level is controllable because of the previous qualification-level tests on the component, equipment and subsystem levels..

anchor: What is the relationship between failure probability and total risk as compared to a specific philosophy?
positive: Failure probability and total risk are explicitly higher than the risk associated with the “two-model” philosophy.9.2.6.8 Project Milestones

anchor: How is the complexity and purpose of monitoring the product life cycle determined?
positive: Monitoring the product life cycle is defined contrac- tually and is performed by specified project milestone reviews. The complexity and purpose are specified by the customer and must be reflected in the project plan, the product assurance plan and the project schedule.

anchor: What is monitored during milestone reviews to facilitate future product cycles?
positive: The milestone reviews (Table 9.2.2) have to moni- tor progress of the project, completion of the schedule and the status of the requirements verification in order to clear the way for the subsequent product cycle.9.2.6.9 Product Assurance PlanningThe planning of the product assurance task must en- sure the early identification of the product assurance

anchor: What phase is considered ideal for early planning of work packages to ensure product realization?
positive: work packages in order to guarantee product reali- zation. The planning has to be performed as early as possible, preferably during the proposal or study phase in order to identify the required extent of product as- surance methods, personnel, personnel qualifications, resources and costs. The product assurance activities are described in detailed work package descriptions (WPDs), as for all other project activities according to the work breakdown structure (WBS) associated with the product life cycle..

anchor: What are the two steps involved in product assurance planning?
positive: The planning is performed in two steps: the timely association of all product assurance activities with the product life cycle in a product assurance task flow; and the technical and programmatic activity description ina written product assurance plan. A precondition is knowing the customer’s quality requirements, project schedule, model and qualification strategy, and deli- verable quality documentation..

anchor: What are the categories into which product assurance activities and costs are classified?

positive: e Environmental conditions, operational condi- tionse Export restrictionse Deliverable documentation.9.2.6.11 Product Assurance Task Flow

anchor: What is the function of the product assurance task flow in relation to project activities?
positive: The product assurance task flow (see Figure 9.2.10) is a supporting tool for preventive planning. It sim- plifies the timely association of PA activities to project activities in a schematic form. The allocation of PA activities is performed for each phase of the product life cycle, demonstrated here by using the example of “design development” (in the tinted boxes). Product Phases/Processes: All phases of the product life cycle (according to DIN 55350) ina timely sequen- ce from the proposal to delivery of the product. Elements: All work steps of the selected product phase and work activities, as described in the work breakdown structure (WBS)..

anchor: What encompasses the actions and techniques tied to the management of space projects?
positive: Project Activities: All project activities of the selected product phase as described in the work package de- scriptions (WPDs).9 Management of Space ProjectsProduct Assurance Activities: All PA activities and methods associated with project activities (see tinted boxes).9.2.6.12 Product Assurance Plan

anchor: What does the PA plan demonstrate regarding customer requirements and referenced documents across project phases?
positive: The PA plan reflects the understanding of customer requirements and referenced documents and describes the associated product assurance program throughout all project phases.

anchor: What activities are involved in verifying the product life cycle from design to acceptance?
positive: The PA program describes the technical and qua- lity activities to check the product life cycle for design development, manufacturing, qualification, integra- tion and acceptance.

anchor: What policy guides the selection of manufacturers and suppliers in contract agreements?
positive: The plan is applicable to the contractor with re- spect to the customer, and is part of the subcontracts with the industrial partners for the space product. The inherent quality policy is also used as a guideline for selected manufacturers and suppliers of equipment, units and components.

anchor: Which phase of the program typically starts with the product phase?
positive: The plan’s sections are considered to be require- ments and must be selected and implemented as appropriate in the associated equipment specifica- tions.The PA program normally starts with Phase B for the product phase and continues in Phase C/D. Specific quality assurance tasks may be continued in Phase E, the operational phase.

anchor: What activities are associated with the timeline and progress tracking in project management?
positive: The PA tasks correlate to the project milestone plan and schedule, for example design reviews, progress meetings, safety reviews and acceptance reviews.

anchor: What standard may guide the organization's internal rules and procedures for the PA program?
positive: The PA program may be supported by the organization’s in-house regulations and procedures according to ISO 9100 as implemented by the prime contractor and the subcontractors.

anchor: What must subcontractors provide to demonstrate adherence to the project’s compliance requirements?
positive: The subcontractors must declare compliance with the system’s PA plan by means of a subcontractor product assurance compliance matrix supported by a sub-PA plan based on their in-house rules, regulations and procedures, both to be approved by the prime contractor before the project starts.

anchor: What processes are involved in managing deviations during procurement planning?
positive: e Procurement planninge Failure, deviation and change managemente Configuration checke Verification checke Content of the quality documentation delive-9.2.7 Risk Management

anchor: What type of risks does the risk policy regularly assess in a company?
positive: Risk management is an iterative process that is app- lied to company processes as well as to products, according to space agency standards. The risk policy for the company assures that the risk inventory and estimation will be performed for business processes and survival risks on a regular basis.

anchor: What is necessary for identifying potential risks within key business processes?
positive: Business risks must be identified by forewarning indicators and thresholds for the organization’s main processes. Identification is supported by the use of the quality indicators.

anchor: Define risk in the context of business and products, including the factors that influence its occurrence.
positive: Risk management assures the implementation of control processes and corrective action in order to avoid or reduce risk. A risk is any event that can have a negative impact on the business or the product, with a certain probability of occurrence, as well as any future event on which the impact is not presently known.

anchor: What key components should be included in a risk management plan according to established processes?
positive: The risk management process must be described in a separate risk management plan which essentially consists of the following activities.

anchor: What is the initial phase in managing potential threats to project goals regarding budget, timeline, and technical efficacy?
positive: Risk Identification: The first step in risk manage- ment is to identify all individual risks that can affect the project’s objectives in terms of cost, schedule and technical performance. The definition of the risk scenario presupposes the assumption of all possible events impacting the product negatively (i.e., the nonachievement of product objectives) and the asso- ciated potential causes of those risks..

anchor: How is the magnitude of risk quantified in project management?
positive: Risk Assessment: The purpose of this step is to determine the magnitude of the individual risks and to rank them with respect to cost, schedule and technical performance. The magnitude of risk is9 Management of Space Projectscalculated as the product of a probability score and a severity score.

anchor: What are the two main aspects evaluated in a risk mitigation assessment for a program?
positive: A risk mitigation table details the criteria used to evaluate the probability of occurrence and the con- sequent severity of an event identified as a risk item for the program.

anchor: What is the primary goal of managing risk in a project?
positive: Risk Reduction: The ultimate purpose of risk management is to reduce the magnitude of risk by proper mitigating actions in order to achieve the product’s objectives; it involves revising the project schedule, budget, scope or quality.Risk Monitoring: The purpose of this step is to ob- serve the monitoring process and corrective actions.

anchor: What are the key activities involved in managing risks during the communication and acceptance phase?
positive: Communication and Acceptance: The purpose of this step is to track, monitor, update, iterate and communicate the risks in order to manage them.

anchor: What are the main objectives of managing configuration in development projects?
positive: 9.2.8 Configuration ManagementConfiguration management (CM) is the progress- oriented management and audit of requirement and design documentation data files, and of the items produced.CM processes are applied for:e Hardware product configuratione Software product configurationThe main objectives of CM are coordination andsynchronization of distributed development and main-

anchor: What are the key stages involved in managing the entire duration of a product's life?
positive: taining control over the product life cycle and the

anchor: What are the key aspects to ensure product consistency amid changes?
positive: maintenance of product consistency despite variousplanned or unplanned changes. CM provides a metho-dical approach by applying methods for:e A well-structured product breakdown and refe- rence configurationse An unequivocal definition of design-to, produce -to, test-to and operate-to documentation and productse Effective and efficient change management for active control

anchor: What processes are involved in tracking and reporting project progress for effective assessment and oversight?
positive: e Status accounting and reporting for progress judgment and monitoring

anchor: What is the intended outcome of centralized approaches in project management related to administrative activities?
positive: e The minimization of administrative activities by centralized approachese Anassurance that everyone working on the project (including subcontractors) at any time is using the2/25/09 3:37:03 PM 9.2 Quality Managementcorrect and accurate documentation and products (e.g., computer programs).

anchor: What role does CM play in ensuring a consistent process within the PA program?
positive: By the above means, CM provides the basis for a coordinated and reproducible process and makes an essential contribution to the PA program.

anchor: What must be included in a configuration management plan related to a specific product?
positive: Documentation management provides the capa- bilities and regulations for establishing and handling all project documentation in order to assure autho- rized preparation, update, storage and delivery based on CM-controlled procedures, independent of the medium on which the information is recorded.CM must be described in a product-dedicated configuration management plan.

anchor: What processes are typically involved in managing system failures and implementing necessary changes?
positive: 9.2.9 Failure and Change Management

anchor: What documentation is required for design corrections related to identified non-conformance?
positive: Failure management monitors all deviations from the contractual product baseline. Each identified non-conformance, for instance manufacturing fail- ures, must be reported in a nonconformance report (NCR) for evaluation by project management. Design corrections or repairs must be documented in the associated product documentation, drawings and procedures.

anchor: What is defined as a condition that fails to meet predetermined criteria or requirements?
positive: Non-conformance is an apparent or proven condi- tion of any item or documentation that does not meet the specified requirements. In addition, any apparent or proven condition of any item or documentation which is considered likely to lead to incorrect opera- tion or failure of the item or mission must be treated as nonconformance. The term non-conformance is also used for failures, discrepancies, defects, anomalies, malfunctions and deficiencies..

anchor: How are non-conformances that impact performance, expenses, timelines, or compliance categorized?
positive: Non-conformances affecting product perfor- mance, costs, schedules or an applicable requirement are generally classified as “major.”

anchor: What must be issued for major NCRs that result in a lasting violation of a requirement?
positive: For major NCRs leading to a permanent violation of a specified requirement, a request for waiver (RFW) must be issued and submitted for customer approval. Details must be reported to the customer together with the information that the product concerned will not fulfill the specifications in the baseline configura- tion of the identification documentation.

anchor: What approaches are used for cost estimations during the initial stages of a project?

During the continuous course of the project more precise cost estimates, based on the subsystem or equipment level, are demanded. At this point more accurate cost estimation methods can be applied since more detailed project information becomes known and available.

anchor: What two indicators are essential for project management in decision-making concerning cost estimation?

Performance indices are calculated and then used to estimate cost at com- pletion (EAC, Estimate At Completion) and cost to complete the project (ETC, Estimate To Complete). Both EAC and ETC are deemed very important indicators for project management in preparing its decisions..

anchor: What is the primary purpose of using expert judgment in estimating costs?
positive: Expert’s Judgment or Wideband Delphi Method This approach is used to derive a rough and rapid estimate of the order of magnitude of a cost. Its rele- vance is normally limited to specific areas and implies expert judgment as well as close familiarity with the field of activity. Such a “rule of thumb” approximation is not very sophisticated, but it may be sufficiently accurate in certain circumstances when an estimate is required quickly..

anchor: What is the method called that starts estimating costs from the lowest level of a project or task?

anchor: What is the primary disadvantage of a detailed cost estimation methodology associated with low-level work packages?
positive: This method derives detailed cost estimates at a re- lative low work package level of the WBS and is clo- sely connected with schedule planning and resource allocation. Due to the amount of detail, a bottom-up estimate is both time consuming and expensive. A precondition for this method is good knowledge and an appropriate level of definition of the activities that have to be estimated.

anchor: What is essential to determine when using historical data for cost estimation?
positive: An important condition for this commonly applied method is being able to ascertain the cost of previous activities, elements or systems. Relevant historical data is used as a reference for predicting the cost of current items. The method depends very much on the com- pleteness and accuracy of the available information and on the extent to which technical, programmatic or economic differences between the reference and the element to be estimated can be identified and utilized to normalize the database. Also, cost trends and any changes in circumstances that might influence the costs must be taken into consideration..

anchor: What factors should be evaluated when comparing bids from different vendors?
positive: Competitive Supplier Proposals

anchor: What is essential for customers to maintain when considering subcontracting activities with limited competition?
positive: Wherever it is intended to subcontract an activity, binding subcontractor proposals probably provide the most reliable estimate. However, each customer should preserve the capability to estimate and assess the cost of activities to be subcontracted. This is es- pecially true whenever there is only little or no real competition, or when subsequent customer-generated modifications are likely.

anchor: What is the role of cost estimation relationships in parametric analysis?
positive: Parametric analysis requires careful consideration of costs as well as technical and programmatic in- formation. This makes it possible to identify cost drivers and to develop cost models. This approach effectively correlates labor costs and personnel with parameters describing the product to be costed. This correlation leads to regression formulas known as cost estimation relationships (CERs). CER can range from simple mathematical relationships to highly complex equations and can be drawn up wherever there is an adequate amount of data available.

anchor: What factors are considered when creating Cost Estimating Relationships for specific technologies?
positive: CERs are typically developed for a particular technology taking into account associated representative parame- ters (such as mass, power or surface) and the model philosophy. The following equation is an example of a simple CER:.

anchor: How are the parameters a and b established in the given technical context?
positive: where parameters a and b are determined by sta- tistical analyses of cost reference data. In this case the technical parameter is P, for example the unit mass, and n could be the number of models to be developed.

anchor: What is crucial for calibrating parametric cost models purchased from the commercial market?
positive: Parametric cost models can be either developed within an organization to analyze its own data or purchased on the commercial market. In the latter case it is essential to calibrate the models with speci- fic reference data from the user’s organization. Even though there may be significant costs associated with developing such models or purchasing licenses for commercial versions, they have a number of advan- tages.

anchor: What are the key benefits of certain evaluative techniques that ensure cost-effectiveness and the ability to trace process evolution?
positive: They allow estimates or assessments to be made fairly rapidly and at relatively low cost, the evolution of the processes involved can be traced, and they can be rerun at a later point in time..

What can be combined with general design parameters to create a specialized cost model for optical instruments?
positive: It is possible to bring together different methods for different cost elements and to merge and develop them further into a specific cost model, for example for optical instruments. Such models might then com- bine general design parameters such as aperture sizes, wavelengths or the type of telescope with more specific parameters such as mass or development effort.

positive: For every method and model the following should be considered:e Application limitations of the modelse Sensitivity of certain parameterse Contract and economic conditionse Impact of the industrial consortiume Need for a plausibility check of the resultse Best opportunity for applying the model results.Last but not least, cost estimates serve the customer as

positive: well as the client as a common basis for understanding.

anchor: What defines the projected cost distributions throughout the project's timeline when integrating work packages?
positive: packages (WPs) into a binding cost baseline, thus defining the cost flows planned for the duration of the project.

anchor: What components are necessary for developing a cost budgeting strategy?
positive: The following information and input are required forthe cost budgeting process:e Work breakdown structure (WBS)e Work package description (WPD)e Cost estimates (e.g., for WPs, subsystems, tasks, assemblies, material, etc.)e Basis of estimate (BoE) (i.e., documentation of the assumptions behind the cost estimates)e Availability of resources (e.g., resource calendar, cost limits, financial planning)

anchor: What type of information is included in contracts regarding costs for outside goods and services?
positive: e Contract information (e.g., prices for external products and services).

anchor: What are the three primary phases involved in developing a cost budget?
positive: Cost budgeting can be broken down into three majorsteps, described as follows:

anchor: What involves combining estimated costs to work packages based on a project breakdown structure?
positive: 1. Aggregation of the Cost Estimates: Allocation of all estimated cost items to WPs according to the project’s WBS. Aggregation of these costs to higher nodes of the WBS, resulting in the total project cost at the top WBS node. In addition, by taking into consideration the schedule information for all WPs, the project’s cost profile (planned spending over time) can be derived.

anchor: What is the purpose of the reserve included in the budget for a project?
positive: 2. Establishing a Management Reserve: The inherent cost risk of a project — analyzed as part of the cost estimation process — is reflected in a management reserve incorporated in the project budget. This reserve can be tapped to fund potential mitigation actions which may become necessary in the course of a project to avoid risks or to reduce the impact of emerging risks. It should be noted that the reserve is not part of the cost baseline, meaning that it is not allocated to specific WPs, and that it can only be used with the authorization of the project ma- nager or customer.

anchor: What organizational levels are considered in the cost risk analysis of a project?
positive: In recent cost risk analyses the overall cost risk of a project is broken down into the hierarchy levels in a project organization which represent the risk source. In this case the project’s management reserve covers only the cost risk contributions directly associated with carrying out.

anchor: What type of risk contributions associated with a project typically fall under corporate responsibility and are not budgeted to the project?
positive: 2/25/09 3:37:18 PM 9.3 Cost Managementa project (e.g., technical development, planning, scheduling). Other cost risk contributions, such as more indirect events stemming from the project environment (e.g., political and market risk) and force majeure, are typically borne at the corporate level (i.e., by the company or space agency) and are thus not budgeted to the project.

anchor: What type of cumulative cost curve is considered ideal for balancing duration and total life cost in development projects?
positive: 3. Smoothing the Cost Profile: The original cost pro- file derived from steps 1 and 2 needs to be adjusted to when financial resources become available. The objective is to facilitate funding by achieving a smooth cost profile which avoids extreme fluctua- tions and remains within the customer’s affordabi- lity limits. In the case of development projects, the best practice regards an S-shaped cumulative cost curve as being the most favorable profile for total life cost, balancing the project’s duration and cost.

anchor: What is the consequence of shifting work tasks or schedules on project execution?
positive: Besides utilizing financing instruments to decouple spending from cost flows, a shifting of WP tasks or schedules might also be required to smooth the cost profile. It should be noted that such activities generally have a detrimental impact on project costing and scheduling. Moreover, the practice could even introduce new conflicts with regard to resource availability and milestones. As such, cost budgeting for a project is an iterative process eventually leading to the project’s cost baseline..

anchor: What is the planned expenditure for scheduled tasks over a project's duration called?
positive: The main outputs of cost budgeting are:e Cost Baseline: Planned cost for scheduled work over the project’s timeline. It is used as a reference for cost and schedule performance measurement.e Funding Plan: Date and amount of funding steps to finance the project costs, aligned with the cost baseline.

anchor: What process requires documentation of changes in adjusted management plans after assessment and acceptance?
positive: e Change Requests (CRs): The cost budgeting pro- cess could result in change requests compared to the project schedule. After being assessed and accepted, such changes have to be documented in adjusted management plans (this is the task of change management).

anchor: What is the primary goal of managing cost-driving elements in a project?
positive: 9.3.4.3 Cost ControlCost control in general can be characterized as the pro- cess of influencing cost driving factors in such a way that cost increases are contained and opportunitiesfor savings are exploited. In addition, cost control comprises the task of tracking and documenting all changes in the cost baseline.

anchor: What are the primary differences between fixed price contracts and cost reimbursement contracts in cost control processes?
positive: The nature of the cost control process also varies with the contract price type, with the distinction usually being between a fixed price contract and a cost reimbursement contract. Their main differences can be described as follows.

anchor: What type of contract is standard for European space projects, where the product scope and deliverables are precisely defined?
positive: In the case of a fixed price contract — which is the standard contract type for space projects in Europe — the product is exactly defined in scope, deliverables and WP effort. This allows a price to be fixed for the end product which includes all margins for profit, escalation/inflation and project risks. If a fixed price needs to be adjusted in the course of the project, the contract has to be changed.

anchor: What document is required to officially amend an original agreement after a change request?
positive: This can be requested by either party through a change request (CR), which must be negotiated and formally agreed by all parties. To become effective the changes have to be documen- ted ina so-called contract change notice (CCN) which amends the original contract..

anchor: What defines the payment structure in an agreement based on reimbursement for incurred expenses?
positive: In a cost reimbursement contract the contrac-

anchor: What type of financial compensation is provided for expenses incurred during work completion?
positive: tor is compensated for the expenses incurred while completing agreed-upon work. The contractor also receives a negotiated profit according to the contract specifics (fixed profit fee or profit percentage). Project risks and inflation are typically borne and paid by the customer. Consequently, for this contract type the cost per product can grow considerably since the effort to achieve a result is reimbursed, in contrast to payment for a completed product in fixed price contracts.

anchor: What advantages do cost reimbursement contracts provide in managing project changes?
positive: On the other hand, this contract type allows adjustments in the project plan to be easily handled by redirecting effort among WPs. If required, the customer is able to exercise direct control over the work program through this mechanism. This flexibility in project execution renders cost reimbursement contracts very suitable for major development or state-of-the-art projects, where typically neither the product nor the work plan can be defined up-front in detail and changes are likely.

anchor: What are the risks associated with cost reimbursement agreements in project management?
positive: n view of cost control, cost reimbursement con- tracts may seem to be disadvantageous, as they bear a higher potential of unwarranted payments which may lead to cost overruns. Additionally, all adjustments to the original baseline have to be assessed with respect to their impact on schedules and cost at completion so that budgets are not exceeded or delays introduced..

anchor: What is the significance of the timestamp in a document recording?
What is the purpose of establishing cost targets per work package in reimbursement agreements?
positive: Accordingly, several precautions are necessary on the customers’ side governing the cost control process in cost reimbursement contracts. First, cost targets per WP are set and scheduled on the project time- line. Even though these targets are not contractually binding, they are utilized as a cost and performance measurement baseline. Second, the customer needs to set up an appropriate progress tracking system to trace accomplished work.

anchor: What indices are derived from the earned value management system for project performance evaluation?
positive: In combination with the perfor- mance measurement baseline this allows assessment of the justification for costs claimed by contractors. In particular, such a system lays the foundation for the earned value management to derive cost and schedule performance indices and to facilitate trend analysis regarding cost at completion, further explained un- der “Methods” in the section below. Moreover, cost discipline should be enforced by bonus agreements for exceeding project performance (e.g., early delivery) and by penalties for underperformance..

anchor: What documentation is essential for tracking project advancements and discrepancies in cost and schedule for aerospace and government contracts?
positive: Cost reimbursement contracts are the standard contract type in the USA for aerospace and govern- ment projects.For both contract types the following input is re- quired:e Project progress reports, documenting work pro- gress and deviations with respect to the project baseline (cost and schedule)

anchor: What document outlines the scope and responsibilities related to the management of a project control process?
positive: e Project management plan (PMP), which in this case specifies the scope and responsibilities asso- ciated with the project control process.

anchor: What are the required reports at the cut-off date during a specified reporting period for projects with cost reimbursement?
positive: Additional input for projects on fixed price con- tracts:e Payment plan (payment milestones)e Contract change notices (CCNs).Additional input for projects on cost reimbursemente Authorized changes to the cost baseline, contract,scope of work, project schedule.e Performance reports at the cut-off date of a speci- fied reporting period. In particular the following reports are required:
