positive: A strict liability implies a higher liability risk: a person damaged does not need to prove that the person responsible for the damage has caused the damage by fault. A strict liability exists, for example in air traffic law for the operation of an aircraft ($3 of the German Air Traffic Act), but not for space activities..

anchor: What legal responsibility does a nation hold for space objects causing damage on Earth or to airborne vehicles?
positive: However, some other states have implemented in their national legislation a strict liability for the launching and reentry of space objects. The reasoning is that a similar concept applies in international law, since the launching state is absolutely liable for damage caused by space objects on the Earth or to aircraft in flight, see Art. II of the Liability Convention.

anchor: How should liability claims be managed if the parties involved cannot agree on applicable law during an international space mission?
positive: Many space activities are conducted under inter- national cooperation. This may raise the question of which national law is applicable to liability issues. Every contract should therefore include a clause agreeing on the applicable law. If the parties have not agreed on this, the law of the place where the con- tractual obligation was accomplished is applicable. If a third party is damaged in the course of a space mission and the context is international, the parties cannot agree on the applicable law. The claims are handled according to the laws of the state in which the damage occurred..

anchor: What options are available for a person seeking compensation for damages caused by a third party?
positive: For damages caused to third parties some specifics have to be taken into account. A person damaged may directly claim for compensation from the person who caused the damage. In addition, a liability of the launching state exists according to the international treaties (Art. VII of the Outer Space Treaty, Arts. I-IV of the Liability Convention). The person damaged may choose whether to claim against the person who caused the damage or against a launching state.

anchor: What is the relationship between a state's liability and the cause of damage in space launches?
positive: The liability of the launching state is not linked to the factor which caused the damage, but only to the par- ticipation of that state in the event of the launch. This international liability also exists when the damage is caused years later in the course of operation or reentry of the object into the Earth’s atmosphere. And this international liability also exists if the damage was caused by the operator.

anchor: What is a requirement for a launching state to seek recourse against an operator for damages?
positive: If the person damaged chooses to claim against a launching state, this state might be interested in taking recourse against the operator or any other person who caused the damage. This can be done only if there is a legal basis in the national laws. This is the case in some states (e.g., Russian Federa- tion, USA, United Kingdom and Australia). Most of these states have at the same time limited this recourse to a certain amount of money, typically the amount of the compulsory third-party liability insurance of the operator. This leads to insurability of the activity and also provides some financial protection for the.

anchor: What is lacking in Germany regarding legal recourse in the national industry?
positive: 2/25/09 3:37:35 PM CHO9.indd Sec1:832national industry. In Germany there is actually no legal basis for such recourse.

anchor: What potential benefit does the liability of launching states provide to space object operators in third-party damage cases?
positive: For any person launching or operating a space object, the additional international liability of the launching states has a positive effect. It can be of ad- vantage for the operator who caused damage toa third party if this third party does not claim compensation against the operator but against a launching state. This launching state may indeed take recourse against the operator. But this recourse is often limited.

anchor: What is the operator's obligation if a direct claim is made by a third party?
positive: Then the operator and the launching state(s) share the liability. Otherwise, in case there is a direct claim of the third party against the operator, the operator has to fully compensate the third party..

anchor: What are the main strategies discussed for dealing with objects in space that no longer serve a purpose?
positive: Another specific aspect of liability issues in outer space is the treatment of space debris. Space debris consists of human-made objects which are in outer space but which have lost their function of using or exploring outer space. Debris may also include former parts of a space object. The avoidance and mitigation of space debris is an important and current topic in many fora. Many approaches are taken.

anchor: What organization has created widely utilized technical standards regarding space debris management?
positive: The most famous might be the approach of the Inter-Agen- cy Space Debris Coordination Committee. It has developed rules which are widely used as technical standards..

anchor: What defines the liability of a launching state for space debris after termination of operation?
positive: If damage occurs despite all efforts to avoid or mitigate debris, the question arises whether or not the (former) operator is liable for such damage. Liability does not end with the termination of operation. Space debris is also regarded as an object which was once launched for the purpose of using or exploring outer space. The launching states are liable regardless of the functional status of the object.

anchor: What determines liability for damage caused by space debris according to the relevant convention?
positive: Their liability is given because of their involvement at the very moment of the launch. If space debris later causes damage and if this damage even was caused after reentry into the Earth’s atmosphere or to aircraft in flight, the launching state is absolutely liable (see Art. II of the Liability Convention). Otherwise it is fault liability (Arts. III, IV of the Liability Convention), but fault is already given if technical standards for avoidance or mitigation of debris were not followed, either willfully or by negligence..

anchor: What liability does an operator face regarding damages caused by debris?
positive: To the same extent the (former) operator is also liable for damages caused by space debris. If the (for- mer) operator has willfully or by negligence omitted9 Management of Space Projectsto consider measures to avoid damage (e.g., to put the object into a graveyard orbit or to bring the object to a controlled re-entry), this may cause liability.

anchor: What condition must an operator meet regarding fuel for orbital maneuvers when using frequency and orbital position rights?
positive: Any operator who has the right to use frequency and orbital position because of a transfer of such rights by the Federal Network Agency are subject to a condition that sufficient fuel has to be retained in order to allow orbital maneuvers to terminate ope- ration. Satellites in a geostationary orbit should be brought into a graveyard orbit or caused to reenter the Earth’s atmosphere according to 3.7 of Administrative Order 8/2005..

anchor: What key organizations are involved in the governance and execution of space initiatives in Europe?
positive: 9.4.3 Space Activities in the Framework of the EU and ESA

anchor: What influences the strategies of private entrepreneurs in space activities?
positive: European activities in outer space have never been exclusively national, bilateral or trilateral activities. There has always been a European dimension. This European dimension is also of relevance for every pri- vate entrepreneur, university or research institution. Every decision taken in the framework of the ESA as well as in the framework of the EU has implications for their activities. Especially those decisions which are of a political and programmatic character and which define their mid-term perspectives can influence the strategy of such non-governmental entities.

anchor: What types of organizations may receive financial contracts from the EU or ESA according to governmental decisions?
positive: It might be interesting for them to orientate according to these governmental perspectives, as there might be financial support forthcoming in the form of grants. Since these decisions define areas in which the EU or ESA might assign contracts to national industry, university or re- search organizations in the future, it is recommended that these decision-making processes on political and programmatic issues at the European level be closely followed to the same extent that the same processes at the national level are followed..

anchor: What are the distinguishing factors that differentiate the EU and ESA as actors in outer space?
positive: Both the EU and ESA have meanwhile become actors in outer space. But both have to be strictly differentiated, also because of their different histories. They will therefore be described separately.

anchor: What body within ESA convenes every two to four years to establish space policy principles?
positive: The main decisions within ESA are made by the Council at ministerial level. This Council is convened every two to four years. It is within this Council that the ESA member states agree on the basic political principles of the organization’s space policy. At the

anchor: What are the legal implications of conducting activities in outer space?
positive: 2/25/09 3:37:35 PM 9.4 Legal Aspects of Space Activities

anchor: What principle dictates the reallocation of funds from ESA to national industries based on member state contributions?
positive: same time the member states designate the amount of their participation within the (optional) program lines of ESA; that is, how much money states will transfer to ESA for executing the programs. As ESA is based on the principle of geo-return, by deciding on the amount of money to be transferred to ESA, the member states decide at the same time about the per- centage of money which is going to be retransferred to their national industry (universities and research organizations).

anchor: What principle requires a member state to conclude contracts with its entities proportional to its financial contributions to a program?
positive: This principle basically says that if a member state pays a certain percentage of money for a defined program, the same percentage value of contracts has to be concluded with entities of that same state for executing this program..

anchor: Which entities are responsible for making key decisions within the European Union?
positive: The main decisions within the EU are made by the Council and the Parliament or within the European Commission. Outer space activities will be explicitly mentioned for the first time in the basic treaties of the EU when the EC Treaty as amended by the Lisbon Treaty enters into force. Therein the competence for carrying out space activities (especially the definition and implementation of programs) will be shared among the EU and the member states.

anchor: What is the proposed measure for the EU regarding space exploration without harmonizing member state laws?
positive: The EU is called on to draw up a European space policy and to establish the necessary measures, which may take the form of a European space program, excluding any harmonization of the laws and regulations of the member states..

anchor: What document outlines the fundamental principles on space by the European Commission?
positive: On another level, the European Commission (which is, broadly speaking, the Executive) has de- cided on some basic principles on space published in its White Paper entitled “Space: a new European frontier for an expanding Union. An action plan for implementing the European space policy.” The White Paper implements European space policy (which is a policy at the EU level and should not be confused with the European Space Policy which recently was agreed between the EU and ESA, see below).

anchor: What are the key roles of GMES and Galileo in relation to international treaties?
positive: Global Moni- toring for Environment and Security (GMES) as well as Galileo have a central role within the White Paper, accompanied by issues on digital divide, outer space for common security and defense policies, monito- ring conflict areas from outer space and monitoring compliance with international treaties and agreement (e.g., treaties on disarmament). Cooperation between the EU and ESA as well as with the Russian Federation is explicitly mentioned within the aims of the policy..

anchor: What are the key components for Europe to attain strategic independence in space activities?
positive: Besides naming these aims, the White Paper also de- fines key elements for achieving them: Europe has to achieve strategic independence from other spacefaring nations, especially with regard to parts and compli- ances for space objects as well as with regard to access to space; the focus is to be on technologies which are of special importance for future developments, and the exploration of outer space and scientific education are considered to be essential elements.

anchor: What is the starting year of the 7th Framework Program initiated by the European Commission?
positive: Also on the level of the European Commission, the 7th Framework Program should be mentioned here. This program started in 2007 and defines the areas in which the European Commission commissions (outer space) research activities to European industries, universi- ties and research organizations. Tendering for these contracts is in full and open competition..

anchor: What formal agreements were established to enhance collaboration between the ESA and the EU?
positive: Cooperation between the EU and ESA has grown in recent years, despite their different histories and tasks, almost conflicting industrial policies and some differences in their member states [9.4.58]. This was decided by the Council of ESA as well as by the Council of the EU. Based on these decisions, coope- ration was formalized in common resolutions of the ESA and EU Councils on a common European Space Policy and on a Framework Agreement for further cooperation.

anchor: What type of cooperation is outlined in the Framework Agreement among parties involved?
positive: The core stipulation of the Framework Agreement is basically that both continue to execute their tasks based on their own internal procedures, but undertake cooperation in scientific activities, techno- logies development, remote sensing, navigation, tele- communication, human space activities, microgravity research and launching activities. In practical terms, the EU participates in the optional ESA programs of Galileo.

anchor: What program marks the initial collaboration between both involved parties?
positive: Galileo is the first huge program in which both bodies cooperate. The second program will be GMES, which is currently being executed by ESA only, but is intended to be transferred to the EU in late 2008. Finally, the Framework Agreement is the basis for the development of a common European Space Policy. In preparation of this policy, a new body was created, the Space Council, which is broadly speaking a union of the Councils of the EU and ESA..

anchor: What factors might influence the potential expansion of collaboration between the EU and ESA?
positive: Whether and to what extent the cooperation between the EU and ESA will be extended to include organizational issues is still written in the stars. Diffe- rent models are being discussed. These discussions are going to be very specific, but in broad terms whether2/25/09 3:37:36 PM 834

anchor: What organizational roles or memberships are being discussed between the ESA and the EU?
positive: ESA might for example become an agency of the EU, or, at the other extreme, whether the EU becomes a member “state” of ESA, is up for discussion [9.4.60].

anchor: What is the primary focus of the literature cited regarding space law?
positive: Von Kries, W., Schmidt-Tedd, B., Schrogl, K.-U. Griindzii- ge des Raumfahrtrechts. Munich: Verlag C.H. Beck 2002, 3lf.Bueckling, A. Der Weltraumvertrag. Cologne: Carl Hey- manns Verlag, 1980.Creola, P. Raumfahrt und Volkerrecht. Zurich: Polygra- phischer Verlag, 1970.

anchor: What are the challenges associated with registering objects launched into space?

anchor: What organization processed the satellite image of Southern Bavaria?

anchor: What significant event in space exploration occurred in October 1957?
positive: 2/27/09 9:33:06 PM Handbook of Space TechnologyFive decades after the launch of the first satellite — Sputnik 1 — in October 1957, this Handbook of Space Technology is intended to provide a comprehensive overview of this exciting field.

anchor: What types of individuals are the intended audience for the handbook regarding space technology?
positive: The handbook, with four-color printing throughout, provides not only students, engineers and scientists but also nonprofessionals who have a serious interest in space activities with detailed insights into the fascinating world of space technology.

anchor: What concepts are integral to understanding the mechanics of orbital motion?
positive: e Introduction (historical overview, space missions)e Fundamentals (orbit mechanics, aerothermody- namics/reentry, space debris, etc.)e Launch Vehicles (stage technology, propulsion systems, launch infrastructure, etc.)e Spacecraft Subsystems (structure, energy supply, thermal regulation, attitude control, communi- cation, etc.)

anchor: What are the critical systems required for sustaining human life during space missions?
positive: e Aspects of Human Space Flight (humans in space, life support systems, rendezvous and docking, etc.)

anchor: What are the key components involved in designing a space system for specific missions?
positive: e Mission Operations (satellite operations, control center, ground station networks)e Utilization of Space (earth observation, commu- nication, navigation, astronomy, material sciences, space medicine, robotics, etc.)e Configuration and Design of a Space System (mis- sion concept, system concept, environmental simu- lation, system design, Galileo satellites, etc.)

anchor: What are the key components involved in overseeing the execution of space missions, including tasks related to budgeting and regulatory compliance?
positive: e Management of Space Missions (project manage- ment, quality management, cost management, space law, etc.)

anchor: What are the stages involved in the lifecycle of space systems including their development and utilization processes?
positive: together with their 42 “subchapters” describe the processes and methodologies behind the develop- ment, construction, operation and utilization of space systems.

anchor: What resources do readers have for further information on specific topics?
positive: The individual chapters and subchapters of this handbook, written by leading experts from univer- sities, research institutions and the space industry, enable the reader who wants information about a selected field to quickly gain a substantial overview. Those who wish to deepen their understanding of individual topics can refer to selected bibliographies as well as an extensive keyword index. The editors have taken care to structure the book in such a way that rea- ders may also find it convenient to read it from cover to cover, thereby accessing a thorough presentation of the current status of space activities..
